name: Red Stewed Olives
name_origin: The Hebrew name provided ('Zeitim b'rotev adom') is a modern descriptive translation used in Israel. The authentic Judeo-Arabic name for this Djerban dish is likely 'Zaytun T'bikh' (Stewed Olives) or 'Zaytun Msharmel' (Olives in Chermoula/Sauce). The word 'Zaytun' is the pan-Semitic word for olive. The preparation method—blanching with turmeric before stewing in a tomato reduction—is distinctively Tunisian. In Djerban dialect, dishes are often named simply by their main ingredient followed by the cooking state (e.g., 'T'bikh'). (Confidence: likely)
description: A classic North African cooked salad where green olives are simmered in a rich, spicy tomato and garlic sauce. The olives are first blanched with turmeric to remove bitterness before being stewed. It is a staple of the 'kemia' (appetizer spread) served on Shabbat.
cultural_context: Common in Tunisian and Moroccan Jewish cuisine, often served as a cooked salad or side dish alongside fish or meat. The use of 'chicken seasoning' (consommé powder) is a common modern Israeli-North African home cooking shortcut.
vegan_adaptation_notes: Use pareve (vegetarian) chicken-flavored consommé powder or vegetable stock powder to make this dish vegan.

steps.instruction: Place the olives in a pot, cover with water, and add the turmeric. Bring to a boil and cook for about 10-15 minutes. This removes excess salt and bitterness. Drain and set aside.
steps.tips: Turmeric helps neutralize the bitterness and gives a nice color.

steps.instruction: In a saucepan, heat the oil and fry the minced garlic briefly until fragrant (do not burn).
Add the tomato paste and spices (paprika, salt, pepper, chicken seasoning). Stir well to open the flavors of the spices.
Add water (approx 1 cup) to create a sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the drained olives to the sauce. Cover and simmer on low heat for about 15-20 minutes until the sauce thickens and coats the olives.
Remove from heat and stir in the chopped cilantro before serving.
steps.tips: Can be served warm or at room temperature.

name_etymology.notes: The Hebrew name provided is purely descriptive. In the context of the Djerban 'Kemia' (appetizer table), this dish is a vegetarian reduction of the famous 'Tajine Zaytun'. The specific technique of using turmeric for blanching is a hallmark of Tunisian Jewish cookery to neutralize bitterness.

alternative_names.name: Zaytun Msharmel
alternative_names.notes: Common Maghrebi term for olives marinated or cooked in a spicy red chermoula sauce.

alternative_names.name: Zaytun T'bikh
alternative_names.notes: Literal translation: 'Stewed Olives'. Used to differentiate cooked olives from raw cured olives.

alternative_names.name: Salatat Zaytun
alternative_names.notes: General term for 'Olive Salad', though this usually implies raw ingredients rather than stewed.

similar_dishes.name: Tajine Zaytun
similar_dishes.similarity: Uses the same flavor profile (olives, lemon, turmeric, tomato).
similar_dishes.key_difference: Tajine Zaytun is a main course braised with meat (veal or chicken), whereas this dish is a vegetarian appetizer (kemia).

similar_dishes.name: Zaytun Msharmel
similar_dishes.similarity: Olives in a red spicy sauce (chermoula).
similar_dishes.key_difference: Moroccan versions often rely heavily on cumin and paprika and are sometimes served cold/raw, whereas the Tunisian version is stewed until soft and often features caraway.

similar_dishes.name: Zeytin Yahnisi
similar_dishes.key_difference: Turkish versions often include onions and olive oil but lack the heavy Harissa/spicy red pepper profile of the Tunisian version.

intro_paragraph: Zaytun means olive in Judeo-Arabic and names this tender cooked salad. Traditionally served as part of the kemia spread, this vegan version simmers blanched green olives in a rich tomato and garlic sauce. It is a savory appetizer perfect for scooping up with fresh bread.

vegan_substitutions.replacement: Vegetable bouillon powder or vegan chicken-style seasoning
vegan_substitutions.notes: Replaces meat-based flavor enhancers while maintaining the savory umami profile
